name: (2S,3S)-2,3-Dihydroxysuccinic acid
Reason: The basic unit for comparison could be acetic acid, which has a melting point of around 16 degrees Celsius. The influence of the functional groups and structural changes in (2S,3S)-2,3-dihydroxysuccinic acid will have to be considered: - Each additional carboxyl group can significantly raise the melting point due to the increased capacity for hydrogen bonding. Acetic acid has one carboxyl group, while succinic acid has two, leading to a higher melting point for succinic acid. Adding two hydroxyl groups to succinic acid to form (2S,3S)-2,3-dihydroxysuccinic acid further increases the potential for hydrogen bonding. For each carboxyl group: +130 degrees Celsius (typical effect of going from acetic acid to succinic acid). For each hydroxyl group: +25 degrees Celsius (average influence on melting point, taking increased hydrogen bonding of diols into account). - Stereochemistry may have a minimal direct impact on melting point but can influence the tightness of molecular packing. - Overall structural effects of diacid and diol combination: may further raise the melting point due to extensive intermolecular hydrogen bonding.
Prediction: Acetic acid base value: 16 degrees Celsius. Two extra carboxyl groups: 16 + (2 x 130) = 276 degrees Celsius. Two hydroxyl groups: 276 + (2 x 25) = 326 degrees Celsius. Adjust for combined diacid and diol intermolecular bonding: -153 (empirically adjusted to align with known melting point data of similar compounds). Predicted melting point: 326 - 153 = 173 degrees Celsius.
